Factorising is the reverse of expanding brackets, so it is, for example, putting 2x² + x - 3 into the form (2x + 3)(x - 1). This is an important way of solving quadratic equations. The first step of factorising an expression is to 'take out' any common factors which the terms have. So if you were asked to factorise x² + x, since x goes into both terms, you would write x(x + 1) .

It is natural that we identify initially the numbers 1, 2, 3, … which we first learnt about as children. These numbers are defined as counting numbers and the set which consists of all these numbers is written using set notation as follows. {1, 2, 3, …}. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 02)
Numbers 1, 2, 3, ... We also define this set as a set of natural numbers. (O / L Mathematics Textbook - Grade 11 - Part 1 - Page 02)

patterns: What is Set of Natural Numbers
Meaning of Set of Natural Numbers
responses: Let us consider again the set of numbers 1, 2, 3,... This set is also defined as the set of natural numbers and is denoted by N That is, N = {1, 2, ...}. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 02)
Numbers 1, 2, 3, ... We also define this set as a set of natural numbers. (O / L Mathematics Textbook - Grade 11 - Part 1 - Page 02)

patterns: What is set of Rational Numbers
Meaning of set of Rational Numbers
responses: Like the integers, fractions too can be considered as numbers, and that operations such as addition and multiplication can be performed on them too. Every integer can be written as a fraction. (For example, we can write 2 = 2/1 ). Further, a fraction can be written in different forms, all having the same numerical value. (For example, 1/2 = 2/4 = 3/6 ). We have also come across negative fractions etc. Although we usually think that the numerator and denominator of a fraction should consist of integers, this is actually not the case. However, fractions with integers in both the numerator and the denominator (apart from 0 in the denominator), have an important place in mathematics. They are called rational numbers. The set of rational numbers is denoted by .(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 03)

Like integers, can be considered numbers, and operations such as addition and multiplication can be performed on them. Each integer can be written as a fraction. (For example, we can write 2 = 2/1). Also, half can be written in different formats, all with the same numeric value. (For example, 1/2 = 2/4 = 3/6). We have also come across negative fractions. Although we generally think that half-numbers and cores should consist of integers, in reality, it is not so. However, fractions with integers (other than 0 in the genre) in both numbers and cores occupy an important place in mathematics. They are called logical numbers. The logical number is shown by the group. (O / L Mathematics Textbook - Grade 11 - Part 1 - Page 03)

patterns: What is Set of Irrational Numbers
Meaning of Set of Irrational Numbers
responses: An irrational number is a real number that cannot be reduced to any ratio between an integer p and a natural number q . The union of the set of irrational numbers and the set of rational numbers forms the set of real numbers. ... Pi and e are examples of special irrationals known as a transcendental numbers. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 04)

An irrational number is a real number which cannot be reduced to any ratio between integers p and natural numbers q. The combination of the set of irrational numbers and the set of rational numbers forms a set of real numbers. ... Pi and e are examples of special irrationality known as occult numbers. (Ordinary Level Mathematics Textbook - Grade 11 - Part 1 - Page 04)

patterns: What is Set of Real Numbers
Meaning of Set of Real Numbers
responses: All the numbers on a number line can be represented by rational numbers or irrational numbers. We call all the rational numbers together with all the irrational numbers, that is, all the numbers that can be represented on a number line, the real numbers. The set of real numbers is denoted by. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 05)

All the numbers in a number line can be represented by logical numbers or irrational numbers. We call all logical numbers and all irrational numbers, that is, all numbers that can be represented by a line of numbers, real numbers. The real numbers are shown by the group. (O / L Mathematics Textbook - Grade 11 - Part 1 - Page 05)

patterns: What is Decimal Representation of a Number
Decimal Representation of a Number is
Meaning of Decimal Representation of a Number
responses: A decimal number is a number where the integer part is separated from the fractional part with the help of a decimal point. The digits are placed to the left and to the right of the decimal to represent numbers greater than or less than one. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 06)

A decimal number is a number that divides integers by halves with the help of a decimal point. The numbers are placed on the left and right decimals to represent more or less than one number. (Ordinary Level Mathematics Textbook - Grade 11 - Part 1 - Page 06)

logarithm is the inverse function to exponentiation. That means the logarithm of a given number x is the exponent to which another fixed number, the base b, must be raised, to produce that number x. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 27)

A pyramid is a polyhedron that has a base, which can be any polygon, and three or more triangular faces that meet at a point called the apex. These triangular sides are sometimes called the lateral faces to distinguish them from the base. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 53)

A pyramid is a polymer with a base that can be any polymer, consisting of three or more triangular faces found at a location called the apex. These triangular sides are sometimes called lateral faces. (O / L Mathematics Textbook - Grade 11 - Part 1 - Page 53)

patterns: What is Difference of Two Squares
responses: If you are asked to factorise an expression which is one square number minus another, you can factorise it immediately. This is because a² - b² = (a + b)(a - b) .
If you are asked to substitute another expression for one square number, you can confirm it immediately. This is because a² - b² = (a + b) (a - b).

Any equation can be solved by trial and improvement (/error). However, this is a tedious procedure. Start by estimating the solution. Then substitute this into the equation to determine whether your estimate is too high or too low. Refine your estimate and repeat the process.

Any equation can be solved by experimenting and improving (/ error). However, this is a tedious procedure. Start by evaluating the solution. Substitute this into the equation to determine if your estimate is too high or too low. Refine your estimate and repeat the process.
It involves rearranging the equation you are trying to solve to give an iteration formula. This is then used repeatedly (using an estimate to start with) to get closer and closer to the answer.
It involves rearranging the equation you are trying to solve to give an iteration formula. This is used repeatedly (using an estimate, to begin with) to get closer and closer to the answer.

Algebraic fractions are simply fractions with algebraic expressions on the top and/or bottom. When adding or subtracting algebraic fractions, the first thing to do is to put them onto a common denominator (by cross multiplying).

Algebraic fractions are simply subdivisions with upper and/or lower algebraic expressions. When adding or subtracting algebraic fractions, the first thing to do is to put them into a common core (by cross multiplication).

patterns: What is Equation of a Straight Line
Equation of a Straight Line is
Meaning of Equation of a Straight Line
responses: Equations of straight lines are in the form y = mx + c (m and c are numbers). m is the gradient of the line and c is the y-intercept (where the graph crosses the y-axis).

A cone has a circular plane surface and a curved surface. The circular plane surface is called the base of the cone. The point through which all the straight lines drawn on the curved surface pass through is called the 'apex' of the cone. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 55)

There is no doubt that you know what properties a sphere has. In mathematics, a sphere is defined as the set of points in three-dimensional space that lies at a constant distance from a fixed point. The fixed point is called the centre of the sphere and the constant distance from the centre to a point on the sphere is called the radius of the sphere. A sphere has only one curved surface and has no edges or vertices. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 59)

patterns: What is Volume of a sphere
Meaning of Volume of a sphere
responses: Recall the circumscribing cylinder of a sphere, that we learned about in the lesson on the surface area of a sphere. Archimedes, the Greek mathematician who explained the surface area of a sphere in terms of the circumscribing cylinder, also explained the volume of a sphere in terms of the volume of the circumscribing cylinder. Let us do the following activity to understand his finding. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 70)

A binomial expression of the form x + y, its square is denoted by (x + y)2, and that what it means is (x + y) (x + y), and that when the product is expanded, the expression x2 + 2xy + y2 is obtained. Moreover, recall that x2 – 2xy + y2 is obtained when (x – y)2 is expanded. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part I - Page 76)
Two algebraic fractions can be multiplied in the same way that two numerical fractions are multiplied (O/L MATHEMATICS Grade 11 Part - I Page 80)

responses: This table contains values from 0.0000 to 1.0000. As in the Tangents Table, the first column contains the angles from 0x to 90x. In the first row right at the top of the table, the minute values, namely 0', 10', 20' etc., and in the Mean Differencescolumn, the values 1', 2', ... 9' appear. This table is used in the same way that theTangents Table is used. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 25)
In trigonometry, the law of cosines relates the lengths of the sides of a triangle to the cosine of one of its angles.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 27)

Angles in a vertical plane is
Meaning of Angles in a vertical plane
responses: A plane which is parallel to the earth (flat ground) is a horizontal plane. A planewhich is perpendicular to a horizontal plane is a vertical plane. A post which is fixed perpendicular to the earth is a vertical post. Such a post is depicted in thefigure.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 33)

patterns: What is Angles in a horizontal plane
Angles in a horizontal plane is
Meaning of Angles in a horizontal plane
responses: You have learnt earlier that bearings are used to indicate directions in a horizontal plane. Bearings provide a measure of an angle that is measured starting from the North and moving in a clockwise direction. Bearings are given using three digits. In modern measuring instruments the distance is also given with the bearing. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 37)

A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers, symbols, or expressions, arranged in rows and columns. The individual items in a matrix are called its elements or entries. Two matrices can be added or subtracted element by element if have the same number of rows and the same number of columns. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 42)

A matrix having a single row. ... A null matrix is also known as a zero matrix, and it is usually denoted by 0. 4. Square matrix: A matrix having equal number of rows and columns. Example: The matrix ( 3 − 2 − 3 1 ) is a square matrix of size 2 × 2 .(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 44)

A matrix having a single row. ... A null matrix is also known as a zero matrix, and it is usually denoted by 0. 4. Square matrix: A matrix having equal number of rows and columns. Example: The matrix ( 3 − 2 − 3 1 ) is a square matrix of size 2 × 2 .(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 44)
A matrix with one column, sometimes used to represent a vector. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 44)

In mathematics, a square matrix is a matrix with the same number of rows and columns. An n-by-n matrix is known as a square matrix of order. . Any two square matrices of the same order can be added and multiplied. Square matrices are often used to represent simple linear transformations, such as shearing or rotation.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 44)

In mathematics, an inequality is a relation which makes a non-equal comparison between two numbers or other mathematical expressions. It is used most often to compare two numbers on the number line by their size.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 57)

A cyclic quadrilateral is a quadrilateral which has all its four vertices lying on a circle. It is also sometimes called inscribed quadrilateral. The circle which consist of all the vertices of any polygon on its circumference is known as the circumcircle or circumscribed circle.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 63)

set is a well-defined collection of distinct elements or members. The elements that make up a set can be anything: people, letters of the alphabet, or mathematical objects, such as numbers, points in space, lines or other geometrical shapes, algebraic constants and variables, or other sets.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 117)

you learnt in Grade 10 that if the occurrence of an event does not depend on the occurrence of another event, then the two events are independent. If A and B are independent we know that P (A∩B) = P(A)P(B). An example of this is given below. Let us consider the random experiment of flipping two coins simultaneously and noting the sides that are face up. It is clear that the side which is face-up on one coin has no influence on the side which is face-up on the other coin. Therefore the side which is face-up on one coin is independent of the side which is face-up on the other coin. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 129)

If the occurrence of an event depends on the occurrence of another event, then they are called dependent events. That is, the occurrence of one event changes the probability of the other event. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 129)
An alternative way of calculating interest for an amount of money borrowed or deposited is the compound interest method. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part II - Page 07)

The Stock Market (Stock Exchange) is a place where securities such as shares anddebentures issued by companies are traded. The Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE) isthe organization responsible for the operation of the stock market in Sri Lanka. TheCSE is licensed by the Securities and Exchange Commission of Sri Lanka (SEC) tooperate as a stock market in Sri Lanka. The SEC regulates and oversees the stockmarket. Companies are admitted to the official list of the CSE as listed companies.On April 21st 2015 there were 297 companies listed in the Sri Lankan stock market.The public who wish to buy or sell securities in the stock market must registerwith one or more of the 15 licensed stockbroker firms of the CSE who attend to thetransactions. Some brokers offer trading through the internet.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part II - Page 11)

Public limited companies which are listed in the stock market, that wish to raisecapital by involving the public, do this by issuing 'shares'. A share is one of theequal parts into which a company’s stated capital is divided.When a company issues new shares, the price of a share is decided by the companyitself. The public can invest in as many shares as they like. An investor who buysshares in a company becomes a part owner of that company. The stake he has in thecompany is proportional to the number of shares he owns.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part II - Page 12)

When a listed company issues new shares, it gives notice of the benefits thatshareholders will enjoy. Dividends are payments out of the earnings of the companywhich some companies give their shareholders as a benefit. It is expressed in termsof the amount paid per share. This is paid out quarterly or annually.For example, a company may pay its shareholders annual dividends of Rs 5 pershare. The company has the right to change this amount with time. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part II - Page 12)

The price at which a share is bought in a company at the initial offering or later atthe market price is called the purchase price of the share and the market price atwhich it is sold is called the selling price of the share.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part II - Page 15)

The midpoint theorem states that The line segment in a triangle joining the midpoint of two sides of the triangle is said to be parallel to its third side and is also half of the length of the third side. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part II - Page 22)

In math, a graph can be defined as a pictorial representation or a diagram that represents data or values in an organized manner. The points on the graph often represent the relationship between two or more things. Then represent the data using a bar graph.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part II - Page 35)

In mathematics, the Pythagorean theorem, or Pythagoras's theorem, is a fundamental relation in Euclidean geometry among the three sides of a right triangle. It states that the area of the square whose side is the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) is equal to the sum of the areas of the squares on the other two sides.(O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 01)

Trigonometry from Greek trigonon, 'triangle' and metron, 'measure' is a branch of mathematics that studies relationships between side lengths and angles of triangles. (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 12)

Trigonometry, the branch of mathematics concerned with specific functions of angles and their application to calculations. There are six functions of an angle commonly used in trigonometry. Their names and abbreviations are sine (sin), cosine (cos), tangent (tan), cotangent (cot), secant (sec), and cosecant (CSC). (O/L MATHEMATICS TEXTBOOK - Grade 11 - Part III - Page 22)
